author: By Jessica Testa and Matthew Avignone
title: Show and Tell
description: Couture shows spilled out onto the streets of Paris.
content: PARIS — What must the early July tourists think of the crowd that descends on this city for the haute couture shows?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Inside a Uvalde Classroom: A Taunting Gunman and 78 Minutes of Terror
description: A teacher who survived the mass shooting recounts the harrowing attack and desperate wait for a rescue.
content: UVALDE, Texas — The first shots came from the hallway outside the classroom. Arnulfo Reyes, a fourth-grade teacher at Robb Elementary School, quickly remembered the active shooter training he had rehearsed so many times and told his 11 students to lie under their desks and “act like you are asleep.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: ‘Hollywood Ending,’ a Cradle-to-Jail Biography of Harvey Weinstein
description: Ken Auletta looks for Weinstein’s Rosebud in this dispiriting account of the former movie mogul’s life.
content: As you might expect, there aren’t a whole lot of laughs in “Hollywood Ending,” Ken Auletta’s cradle-to-jail new biography of Harvey Weinstein, the movie mogul convicted of third-degree rape and another sex felony in New York and awaiting trial on further charges in California. When Auletta calls Weinstein’s relationship with his brother Bob “Shakespeare-worthy,” he is placing the story squarely in the tragedy column of the ledger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Mets and Yankees Sending 10 Players to All-Star Game
description: Pete Alonso makes his return to the Midsummer Classic and he will be joined by three teammates and six Yankees players.
content: Pete Alonso of the Mets, who has become something of a fixture at Major League Baseball’s All-Star week, will come off the bench for the National League in this year’s All-Star Game. Alonso, the two-time defending Home Run Derby champion, will be joined in Los Angeles by three of his Mets teammates and six players from the crosstown Yankees, who led all teams in total selections once the pitchers and reserves were announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Novak Djokovic Defeats Nick Kyrgios to Win His Seventh Wimbledon Title
description: Djokovic dropped the first set of the men’s singles final, but won the next three to capture his 21st Grand Slam title.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — The opponents and details change from year to year, but the bottom line has remained the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aquilino Gonell
title: I Was Betrayed by President Trump
description: My career as a Capitol policeman was cut short when I was beaten on Jan. 6 trying to defend our democracy.
content: As one of the Capitol Police officers who defended the United States against the mob on Jan. 6, 2021, I felt it was important for me to be in the committee room on June 28 to hear the former White House aide Cassidy Hutchinson’s testimony. Along with three colleagues, I went, even though I knew it would be difficult to relive the horrors I witnessed. Although I experienced firsthand the brutal onslaught of the insurrectionists, I was shocked to hear Ms. Hutchinson explain the extent to which former President Donald Trump incited the people who almost killed me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Despite Repeated Fumbles, Georgia Republicans Say They’re Sticking With Walker
description: Republicans are standing behind Herschel Walker, the former football star, despite an array of revelations, missteps and questions about his qualifications for a Senate seat.
content: ATLANTA — Georgia Republicans knew for months before Herschel Walker launched his Senate campaign that he would be a huge risk in one of the party’s most pivotal races. Just how much of a risk has become clear to many of them in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Biden Will Find a Changed Middle East on His Coming Visit
description: On his first trip to the region since taking office, President Biden will begin in Israel, which has been building relations with Arab nations. He will also make a stop in Saudi Arabia.
content: JERUSALEM — When President Biden arrives in the Middle East this week, on his first visit as American head of state, he will find a region where alliances, priorities and relations with the United States have shifted significantly since his last official trip, six years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: In N.Y.C. Apartments, the Ants Go Marching Up
description: Like many ambitious New Yorkers, the ManhattAnt is a social climber.
content: When Katie Guhl traveled at the end of May — to a wedding in New Orleans and a Memorial Day gathering in New Jersey — she left her apartment on East 81st street spotless. So when she returned home to find swarms of ants in her kitchen, she was livid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Airline Pilots Seek Big Raises, and Broader Changes
description: Pilots feel frustrated and overworked, issues that they say the air travel rebound has magnified by disrupting operations.
content: Staffing shortages, bad weather, high fuel prices and runaway inflation — airlines face plenty of challenges as they seek to benefit from a strong travel rebound. But there’s at least one other complication in the mix: negotiating new pilot contracts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: What a Reckoning at the Supreme Court Could Look Like
description: Biden’s Supreme Court commission report offers a thorough and at times exciting way to think about court reform.
content: Late in the lead-up to the 2020 presidential election, as Mitch McConnell rushed to replace Ruth Bader Ginsburg with Amy Coney Barrett, the left began pushing Joe Biden to endorse adding seats to the Supreme Court. Biden, in response, did what politicians do when faced with an issue they don’t want to think about: He promised to create a commission to study the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Goose Bumps Build for the Webb’s First Snapshots of the Universe
description: NASA picked five new images of scenes from around the universe that it hopes will knock the public’s socks off. Get ready for astronomical records to be broken.
content: On Tuesday morning, NASA will show off the first pictures and data from the new James Webb Space Telescope. That will bring to an end some 30 years and $10 billion of planning, building, testing and innovating, followed by 6 months of terror, tension and anticipation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Draper
title: Cassidy Hutchinson: Why the Jan. 6 Committee Rushed Her Testimony
description: Sequestered with family and security, Ms. Hutchinson, 26, has in the process developed an unlikely bond with Representative Liz Cheney, the panel’s vice chairwoman.
content: WASHINGTON — The day before Cassidy Hutchinson was deposed for a fourth time by the Jan. 6 committee, the former Trump White House aide received a phone message that would dramatically change the plans of the panel and write a new chapter in American politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: We Are Political Hostages
description: For most people, “freedom of choice” in elections is an illusion. We are captives of the two-party system.
content: One of our greatest errors as a country has been our nonstop campaign to convince generations of voters that elections are about freedom of choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: 15-Year-Old Arrested in Fatal Stabbing of 14-Year-Old in Subway
description: The teenager who died appeared to have known his attacker, officials said. A dispute between them in the street spilled into the subway.
content: A 15-year-old boy was arrested on Sunday and charged with murder in the stabbing death of a 14-year-old boy in a subway station in Harlem, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Canada will return a sanctioned Nord Stream 1 turbine to ease Germany’s gas crisis.
description: The turbine — a critical piece of pipeline equipment — had been sent to Canada for repairs, but its return had been held up by sanctions against Russia.
content: Canada’s government said it would permit the return of a turbine to Germany that’s needed to operate a key Russian pipeline, a step intended to help Berlin ease a natural-gas shortage that has sent prices soaring but one that was taken over the objections of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Wildfire in Yosemite National Park Imperils Century-Old Trees
description: Nearly a dozen helicopters and more than 360 firefighters were at the Washburn fire, which has grown to more than 2,000 acres.
content: A wildfire in Yosemite National Park that has spread over 2,000 acres is threatening a grove of hundreds of giant sequoia trees, including some that are centuries old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: The G.O.P.’s ‘Wildest Dream’
description: The election of Mayra Flores, a Republican and an immigrant, helps explain how Latino voters are shifting to the right.
content: Latino voters have recently shifted toward the Republican Party. Most still vote for Democrats, but the margin has shrunk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: In the capital of Sri Lanka, high spirits and curiosity from the protesters.
description: Hours after protesters took control the building, it has effectively become a free museum. People stream in and admire the art as Army guards quietly patrol the halls.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Hundreds of people walk around a makeshift protest camp erected outside the presidential mansion, the morning after it was stormed by largely peaceful protesters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Taylor
title: The Many Grievances of the Broke, Tech-Averse Liberal
description: It’s a hard world out there for the protagonist of Teddy Wayne’s novel “The Great Man Theory.”
content: Paul, the protagonist of Teddy Wayne’s new novel, “The Great Man Theory,” is an aggrieved Everyman who finds contemporary life unsatisfying. He eschews screens and seeks to preserve his capacity for deep, sustained thought about the things that matter to him — the environment, politics, history and the fight against the tyranny of the ready-made that orders so much of life today. Put another way, he’s the kind of annoying man you sometimes encounter out in the world: overserious, tiresomely enraged and boring at parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: In Spite of Pitching Woes, the Red Sox Keep Swinging
description: Injuries have hampered the team’s already fragile rotation, but a powerful offense has kept Boston in the postseason hunt.
content: BOSTON — Chris Sale stopped by his locker at Fenway Park for about a minute on Saturday afternoon, just long enough to shake hands and thank a visitor for wishing him well. He was scurrying between the field and the weight room, slipped a new shirt over his reedy frame — “SALE” tattooed between his shoulder blades — and off he went.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Austin Ramzy
title: As they took over the president’s house, Sri Lankan protesters stopped to savor its luxuries.
description: Images from Colombo showed demonstrators enjoying a rare moment of levity, after months of economic deprivation.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — They did flips into the pool. They lounged on canopied beds. And, on wide-screen televisions, they watched cricket and news footage of their fellow protesters, who had massed in Sri Lanka’s capital and joined them in storming the presidential residence and secretariat.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Metropolis of 5 Million, Rainforest Is a Lifeline and a Junkyard
description: An endangered gem of lush greenery in Abidjan, Ivory Coast’s economic hub, is at the center of government efforts to promote ecotourism. Those who live and work there worry about what it means for them.
content: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast — The clangs of the men’s chisels and hammers were deafening as they dismantled a rusty truck, the din only fading as it reached the dense forest encircling them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Moira Donegan
title: In Rust Belt Ohio, the First American Rape Case to Go Viral
description: In “Roll Red Roll,” Nancy Schwartzman revisits a teenage girl’s 2012 assault by high school football players, and its aftermath.
content: It’s the grim ordinariness of the Steubenville rape case — an August 2012 incident involving an unconscious teenage girl, members of a revered high school football team and the small town that protected the perpetrators — that shines through most brightly in Nancy Schwartzman’s “Roll Red Roll.” A meticulous account of the “first rape case ever to go viral in the United States,” the book moves from the facts of one summer night in Rust Belt Ohio into a broader reckoning with American masculinity and the emerging influence of the internet on sexual assault cases. Schwartzman clearly conveys the brutal banality of what happened in that town, the way rape culture, victim blaming and institutional complicity are the rule rather than the exception in American communities. Steubenville could be anywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Shinzo Abe’s Party Triumphs in Parliamentary Vote, Extending Legacy
description: The Liberal Democrats and their partners gained enough seats to form a supermajority. They can now amend the country’s pacifist Constitution.
content: TOKYO — Two days after Japan’s former prime minister  Shinzo Abe was gunned down at a campaign stop on Friday, his Liberal Democratic Party and its allies swept to victory in a parliamentary election that gave them a chance to pursue Mr. Abe’s long-held ambition of revising Japan’s pacifist Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What We Know About the Protests in Sri Lanka
description: Months of demonstrations over dire economic conditions culminated in a peaceful takeover of the presidential residence and promises of resignations.
content: Months of protests in Sri Lanka reached a crescendo on Saturday when demonstrators stormed into the official residence of the president and the private home of the prime minister. The protesters say the leaders are responsible for the corruption and mismanagement that led to the collapse of the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Mujib Mashal
title: Embattled Leaders in Hiding, Sri Lankans Ask: What’s Next?
description: Protesters in Sri Lanka roamed the halls and grounds of power without challenge as they waited to see who would take the reins of their economically devastated country.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Sri Lanka’s political and economic crisis offered a peculiar tableau Sunday after a day of high drama: The protesters were everywhere, cooking in the prime minister’s garden and even lounging in the president’s bedroom while the leaders were nowhere to be seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Djokovic vs. Kyrgios: How to Watch the Wimbledon Men’s Singles Final
description: Djokovic, a six-time Wimbledon champion, plays Nick Kyrgios, who is appearing in his first Grand Slam singles final.
content: Novak Djokovic Defeats Nick Kyrgios to Capture the Wimbledon Title. Read the latest here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: If Only John Roberts Would Retire
description: To help preserve the credibility of the Supreme Court, Chief Justice John Roberts should resign.
content: If liberal dreams — so endearing, so enduring — really did come true, Chief Justice John Roberts would resign. He’s been at it for 17 years. And he’s been incapable of tempering the Federalist Society-stamped fanatics on the right or leading the court toward any semblance of justice for all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Built to Be Flexible, Novak Djokovic Bounces Back
description: After forgoing a Covid-19 vaccine complicated his schedule, Djokovic’s elasticity this year has gone beyond the reactive shots that helped him win a seventh Wimbledon men’s singles title.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — He is an elastic man, Novak Djokovic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Sri Lanka needs billions of dollars as it exhausts its sources of financing.
description: Funds provided by India are already gone. China has kept its distance. As the crisis deepens, Sri Lanka has even turned to charities in Qatar for help.
content: Sri Lanka needs $6 billion through the end of the year to buy fuel and other essential goods to stabilize its crumbling economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Cecilia Kang
title: The Fight Over Truth Also Has a Red State, Blue State Divide
description: Several states run by Democrats are pushing for stiffer rules on the spread of false information, while Republican-run states are pushing for fewer rules.
content: To fight disinformation, California lawmakers are advancing a bill that would force social media companies to divulge their process for removing false, hateful or extremist material from their platforms. Texas lawmakers, by contrast, want to ban the largest of the companies — Facebook, Twitter and YouTube — from removing posts because of political points of view.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘As the Vehicle Approached, I Stood My Ground and Waved for It to Halt’
description: A seaside routine nearly interrupted, a pizza lesson in Brooklyn and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: One Small Step for Democracy in a ‘Live Free or Die’ Town
description: A cautionary tale from Croydon, N.H., where one man tried to foist a change so drastic it jolted a community out of political indifference.
content: CROYDON, N.H. — The tiny New Hampshire town of Croydon fits the New England of the imagination, with its cozy general store, one-room schoolhouse and local museum open by appointment. The only thing missing is supposed to be missing: a stoplight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Jack Healy, Frances Robles and Shaila Dewan
title: After Another Mass Shooting, Questions Loom About the Role of Parents
description: Mothers and fathers of young men accused in shootings, including the 21-year-old charged in the massacre in Highland Park, Ill., have faced scrutiny.
content: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill. — Days after a gunman opened fire at a Fourth of July parade here, Alberto Fuentes arrived at a downtown memorial for the victims, asking himself a question now haunting many in this shattered Chicago suburb: Could the 21-year-old suspect’s parents have prevented any of this?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for $550,000 or Less
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
title: Bannon, Facing Jail and Fines, Agrees to Testify to Jan. 6 Panel
description: Stephen K. Bannon, the former Trump campaign manager and White House adviser, made the abrupt about-face after the former president authorized him to talk to investigators.
content: WASHINGTON — With his criminal trial for contempt of Congress approaching, Stephen K. Bannon, an ally of former President Donald J. Trump’s who was involved in his plans to overturn the 2020 election, has informed the House committee investigating the Capitol attack that he is now willing to testify, according to two letters obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 10, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 10, 2022.
content: An article on Page 4 this weekend about the new host of NPR’s “Code Switch” misidentifies the platform that hosts “This American Life.” It is delivered to stations by Public Radio Exchange, not NPR.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivek Shankar and Mujib Mashal
title: The president has not been heard from since protesters overran his residence, fueling questions about who is in charge.
description: The uncertainty about who is leading Sri Lanka deepened on Sunday, as protesters occupied the halls of the presidential residence and office and President Gotabaya Rajapaksa had not yet addressed reports that he plans to resign later this week.
content: The uncertainty about who is leading Sri Lanka deepened on Sunday, as protesters occupied the halls of the presidential residence and office and President Gotabaya Rajapaksa had not yet addressed reports that he plans to resign later this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Week in Business: A Rude Awakening for Start-Ups
description: Job growth remained strong last month. Company earnings season kicks off. And Elon Musk backs away from his deal for Twitter.
content: For many tech start-ups, the era of seemingly endless optimism and immunity — from scrutiny, skepticism and, most of all, serious legal consequences — began to fray when an exposé on the blood-testing company Theranos was published in 2015 that raised questions about the effectiveness of the company’s technology. On Thursday, a jury found Ramesh Balwani, Theranos’s No. 2 executive, guilty of 12 counts of fraud, delivering another potent warning to Silicon Valley. Prosecutors’ evidence against Mr. Balwani showed that he had been deeply involved in almost every aspect of the company and had knowingly misled investors and customers. The verdict was more severe than that of Elizabeth Holmes, the Theranos founder and chief executive, who in January was convicted of four counts of fraud. It also arrives amid other troubling signs in the start-up world: Tech stock prices have plummeted this year, and investors have become more risk averse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: Sri Lanka in Turmoil
description: Plus Shinzo Abe’s allies win a supermajority in Japan’s parliament and Russia bombards Donetsk.
content: An official said President Gotabaya Rajapaksa had agreed to resign as the leader of Sri Lanka after protesters took over his house on Saturday. Rajapaksa hasn’t been seen since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: At Least 21 Dead After 3 Tavern Shootings in South Africa
description: The shootings further highlighted concerns about safety, coming only two weeks after 21 teenagers died mysteriously in a coastal city tavern.
content: JOHANNESBURG — At least 21 people were killed over the weekend as gunmen opened fire on three taverns in South Africa, in what the police described as “random” shootings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Eureka!
description: Discover Roy Greim’s colorful New York Times Crossword debut.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Eureka! We’ve found it! The Monday crossword is here at last. Today’s puzzle is a New York Times Crossword debut by the constructor Roy Greim. Joel Fagliano, the senior puzzle editor for The Times, told me that this puzzle stood out to the editors for the “simple yet delightfully creative idea” anchoring its theme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Some Surprising Good News: Bookstores Are Booming and Becoming More Diverse
description: More than 300 bookstores have opened in the past couple of years — a revival that is meeting a demand for “real recommendations from real people.”
content: People told Lucy Yu it was a crazy time to open a bookstore in Chinatown. It was early 2021, and the pandemic had devastated the neighborhood, forcing dozens of stores and restaurants to close. The rise of anti-Asian hate crimes had shaken residents and local business owners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: An Ode to Bookstores and Promiscuous Reading
description: I believe in bookstores in part because I believe in pluralism.
content: Bookstores, like wines, have different notes, different flavors, each one distinct. There are the musty, quirky ones with haphazard piles and dusty rows, usually with both used and new books. There are the small indie stores, quaint, cozy and scrappy. Then there’s the big-box gleam of long, straight rows, bright and dustless, with a café and a kids section you can get lost in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman
title: Defense Firm Said U.S. Spies Backed Its Bid for Pegasus Spyware Maker
description: The American contractor L3 Harris is said to have cited support from intelligence officials for its effort to acquire NSO, the Israeli spyware company blacklisted by the Biden administration.
content: A team of executives from an American military contractor quietly visited Israel numerous times in recent months to try to carry out a bold but risky plan: purchasing NSO Group, the cyber hacking firm that is as notorious as it is technologically accomplished.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Ukraine War Now a Battle of Endurance
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 10, 2022.
content: “I worry about the fatigue factor of the public in a wide range of countries because of the economic costs and because there are other pressing concerns.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Shauntel Lowe
title: Brittney Griner is honored by her fellow players at the W.N.B.A. All-Star Game.
description: The league made Griner, who has been detained in Russia since February, an honorary starter for the game.
content: CHICAGO — Brittney Griner’s fellow W.N.B.A. players honored her during the league’s All-Star Game in Chicago on Sunday, wearing jerseys bearing her name and number for the second half.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Tennis Is Done With Covid-19, but the Virus Isn’t Done With Tennis
description: With testing, quarantine and isolation requirements all but gone, tennis finally seems to have entered a stage of pandemic apathy, much like a lot of society.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — With the final match looming, this year’s edition of Wimbledon has already proven many points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Moll
title: What We Know About the Shinzo Abe Assassination
description: The police in Nara, Japan, say a 41-year-old man was responsible for the fatal shooting of the former prime minister, but have given few details about the suspect.
content: Shinzo Abe, the former prime minister of Japan who held the office longer than anyone else, was fatally shot on Friday while giving a speech for a political candidate in the city of Nara.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: With schools long shut, a father sees the protests in Sri Lanka as education.
description: Mohammad Imran’s children have barely attended school because of the nation’s economic crisis. And he says his salary barely covers the basics.
content: For more than two years, Mohammad Imran’s two children have been unable to attend school regularly in Colombo, the capital of Sri Lanka. First it was the pandemic. Now, it’s the economic crisis, where fuel has become scarce and the cost of everything from food to transportation has skyrocketed on the island nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: In Eastern Ukraine, Attacks Intensify as Russia Readies New Offensive
description: The civilian toll has risen sharply in recent days as rockets and shells strike residential areas in the likely path of Russia’s coming push into Donetsk Province.
content: CHASIV YAR, Ukraine — Russia’s offensive in eastern Ukraine is intensifying in Donetsk Province, with a string of towns and villages coming under bombardment in the last week as Russian troops turn their firepower farther west after seizing control of the last city under Ukrainian control in Luhansk Province.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan W. Rosen
title: The Most Talented Runner of His Generation Takes the Unexpected Route Back Home
description: Forty-four years ago, Henry Rono set multiple world records on the track. Much of his life was later overshadowed by addiction. But at 70, he has no regrets.
content: KIPTARAGON, Kenya — One afternoon in May, as a cold rain pelted the roof of his brother’s rural home, Henry Rono sipped a mug of tea and reflected on what he called his greatest achievement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Desperate for Recruits, Russia Launches a ‘Stealth Mobilization’
description: Leery of a national draft for the Ukraine war, the Kremlin is offering cash bonuses and employing strong arm tactics.
content: Four Russian veterans of the war in Ukraine recently published short videos online to complain about what they called their shabby treatment after returning to the Russian region of Chechnya, after six weeks on the battlefield.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Illustrations by Agnes Lee
title: A Scooter Mystery Solved
description: Wondering who rides a cherry-red Vespa.
content: Wondering who rides a cherry-red Vespa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Protesters in Sri Lanka Maintain Control of Government Buildings
description: Hundreds of people in Colombo, Sri Lanka, continued to occupy President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s home and office, as well as the prime minister’s home, a day after demonstrators stormed the buildings in protest of the island nation’s economic crisis.
content: Hundreds of people in Colombo, Sri Lanka, continued to occupy President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s home and office, as well as the prime minister’s home, a day after demonstrators stormed the buildings in protest of the island nation’s economic crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Russian Airstrike Hits an Apartment Complex in Eastern Ukraine
description: Emergency crews combed through rubble, looking for survivors, after a deadly Russian attack killed more than a dozen people in Chasiv Yar, Ukraine. Some residents were rescued, but more were trapped under the ruins.
content: Emergency crews combed through rubble, looking for survivors, after a deadly Russian attack killed more than a dozen people in Chasiv Yar, Ukraine. Some residents were rescued, but more were trapped under the ruins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Wolfe, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Corey Schreppel and Jeremy McLennan
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Rise and Fall of America’s Environmentalist Underground’
description: This year, one of the last fugitives of the Earth Liberation Front pleaded guilty to arson — at a moment when climate activists are again flirting with radical ideas.
content: Warning of imminent ecological catastrophe, the Earth Liberation Front became notorious in the late 1990s for setting fire to symbols of ecological destruction, including timber mills, an S.U.V. dealership and a ski resort. The group was widely demonized. Its exploits were condemned by mainstream environmental groups, ridiculed by the media and inspired a furious crackdown from law enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: One-pot chermoula shrimp, gazpacho and more recipes for the days ahead.
content: Good morning. My pal Kim Severson is a national correspondent for our Food desk. She’s based in Atlanta and, while we jawbone on the phone all the time, we don’t get to spend as much quality time around a dining table as when she worked in New York. The pandemic hasn’t helped matters. I don’t think we’ve been able to see one another in person more than a couple of times since March of 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Ruling From Outside the Court: ‘Shame’ on the Justices
description: It’s the readers’ turn to judge ... the Supreme Court’s recently ended term. Also: Anti-abortion activists; banning AR-15s; Australian slang.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
